abstract.p: Article discusses play of New York Jets running back Curtis Martin in victory over Tampa Bay Buccaneers (M)

block.p: The play had been a certified flop for the Jets in practice last week, but Curtis Martin, who makes his living running the football, promised his passing would improve in today's game. And it did.

With less than a minute to play and the Jets trailing Tampa Bay, 17-14, Martin took a handoff from Vinny Testaverde, just as he had on the previous play. Except this time he lofted a pass to wide receiver Wayne Chrebet, who was wide open in the end zone.
The play had been a certified flop for the Jets in practice last week, but Curtis Martin, who makes his living running the football, promised his passing would improve in today's game. And it did.

With less than a minute to play and the Jets trailing Tampa Bay, 17-14, Martin took a handoff from Vinny Testaverde, just as he had on the previous play. Except this time he lofted a pass to wide receiver Wayne Chrebet, who was wide open in the end zone.
Chrebet admittedly jumped too soon as the ball headed toward him, but he snagged the football to give the Jets a dramatic 21-17 victory.

Never mind that Martin hadn't thrown a pass in a game in a decade -- since high school. Or that Chrebet, put down continually by the former Jets receiver Keyshawn Johnson, had just one catch in the game to that point.

''They actually laughed at me,'' Martin said of his practice attempts as a passer. ''That play was the joke of the week in practice. The first time we ran it, I rolled out and threw it and it just wobbled. Everybody went, 'Quack, quack, quack.' But I told 'em: 'You all just wait for the game. I'll get it done in the game.' ''
Martin had gained 6 yards with a handoff on a play from the Bucs' 24-yard line.
''The obvious thing is we're going to run that toss again,'' center Kevin Mawae said. ''They bit for it big.''
Martin said he never saw Chrebet catch the ball. ''That was the hardest hit I took all day,'' he said, referring to the Bucs' pass rush on the play.
Chrebet lined up for the play remembering how shaky Martin had looked in practice, but also thinking this was the perfect time to catch the Bucs off guard.
''He hadn't thrown well, but I had told him, 'Man, just throw it out there,' '' Chrebet said. ''And he hit me in the mouth with it.''

The reserve running back Bernie Parmalee said the Jets ran the play at least 10 times at practice one day, and Martin looked like, well, a running back. The Jets' offensive coordinator, Dan Henning, told a different story.
''He was 2 for 2 with it in practice,'' Henning said. ''But he didn't throw as pretty a pass as he did today.''
Henning said it took no guts to call the play. ''I just asked Al and he said, 'Go with it,' '' he said of Coach Al Groh.

Chrebet noted that he was so eager to make the catch that he jumped before the ball got there. ''Fortunately, I was able to hang in the air for a while,'' he said, smiling. ''I wasn't going to miss that ball if there was any way possible.'' The catch gave Chrebet a big last laugh against Johnson, who during the week had described Chrebet as a mere flashlight compared with his own status as a full-scale star.
''On that catch, there were a lot of flashbulbs going off, and they were for one guy,'' Mawae said. ''I want to be humble about this, but it's hard. I'm just thrilled to death.''
Chrebet didn't want to participate in any gloating as far as Johnson was concerned.
''Sweet? Redemption? None of that means anything to me,'' Chrebet said. ''The whole thing is the Jets are 4-0 and that's the story.''

Until the frantic finish -- set up by two fumble recoveries -- the Jets' offense had been held in check by Tampa Bay. The Bucs' defense intercepted Testaverde three times, including a 37-yard touchdown return by cornerback Ronde Barber. With 10 minutes 1 second left in the game, Groh replaced Testaverde with Ray Lucas, but only for a series.

''A lot of things weren't working today,'' Chrebet said. ''But the thing is, you don't stop trying. If you keep plugging away, good things are going to happen. I believe that, and I think that was evident on that last catch.''
In his postgame interviews, Chrebet grew weary of hearing Johnson's name.
''I could say things and point fingers, but I'm bigger than that,'' he said. ''I play for the New York Jets, and that's all Wayne Chrebet cares about.''
